t: Proverbs 21
In*pn the Lord’s*s hand the king’s heart is a stream of water that*ld he channels toward all who please him.
A*pn person may think their own ways are right, but*ld the Lord*s weighs the heart.
To*pn do what is right and just is*ld more acceptable to the Lord*s than sacrifice.
Haughty*pn eyes and a proud heart— the*ld unplowed field of the wicked—produce sin.
The*pn plans of the diligent lead to profit as*ld surely as haste leads to poverty.
A*pn fortune made by a lying tongue is*ld a fleeting vapor and a deadly snare.
The*pn violence of the wicked will drag them away, for*ld they refuse to do what is right.
The*pn way of the guilty is devious, but*ld the conduct of the innocent is upright.
Better*pn to live on a corner of the roof than*ld share a house with a quarrelsome wife.
The*pn wicked crave evil; their*ld neighbors get no mercy from them.
When*pn a mocker is punished, the simple gain wisdom; by*ld paying attention to the wise they get knowledge.
The*pn Righteous One takes note of the house of the wicked and*ld brings the wicked to ruin.
Whoever*pn shuts their ears to the cry of the poor will*ld also cry out and not be answered.
A*pn gift given in secret soothes anger, and*ld a bribe concealed in the cloak pacifies great wrath.
When*pn justice is done, it brings joy to the righteous but*ld terror to evildoers.
Whoever*pn strays from the path of prudence comes*ld to rest in the company of the dead.
Whoever*pn loves pleasure will become poor; whoever*ld loves wine and olive oil will never be rich.
The*pn wicked become a ransom for the righteous, and*ld the unfaithful for the upright.
Better*pn to live in a desert than*ld with a quarrelsome and nagging wife.
The*pn wise store up choice food and olive oil, but*ld fools gulp theirs down.
Whoever*pn pursues righteousness and love finds*ld life, prosperity and honor.
One*pn who is wise can go up against the city of the mighty and*ld pull down the stronghold in which they trust.
Those*pn who guard their mouths and their tongues keep*ld themselves from calamity.
The*pn proud and arrogant person—“Mocker” is his name— behaves*ld with insolent fury.
The*pn craving of a sluggard will be the death of him, because*ld his hands refuse to work.
All*ln day long he craves for more, but*ld the righteous give without sparing.
The*pn sacrifice of the wicked is detestable— how*ld much more so when brought with evil intent!
A*pn false witness will perish, but*ld a careful listener will testify successfully.
The*pn wicked put up a bold front, but*ld the upright give thought to their ways.
There*pn is no wisdom, no insight, no plan that*ld can succeed against the Lord.*s
The*pn horse is made ready for the day of battle, but*ld victory rests with the Lord.*s
